This game is great! It took a little time to get into, but afterwards I really started to enjoy it. It isn't a long game, but it has a very nicely done story, challenging gameplay, fun battle system, and amazing artwork. The narrator does a great job throughout the game, and I can appreciate the hidden 'extras' that are integrated into the game. (Going on a spree of destroying the environment cues the narrator to say 'Kid just rages for a bit.'). Below is my review for Bastion which I have given a 9/10.     Story - The story is basically about an event that happened called 'The Calamity', and pits you in the role of a survivor trying to learn more about what happened, all the while restoring a grand ship called 'The Bastion' whose significance you don't learn about until later. The story is told through the narrator's narration of your actions as you work your way through the game. It is mainly a giant fetch quest, ('We need X of these to restore the Bastion'). But the allure of this game is that you have no idea what the story is at the beginning, and your only way of learning more is by completing levels to learn more from the narrator as you work through the level and eventually return from the mission.     Gameplay - The overall gameplay is fun, fast paced, and challenging. The game was very well balanced and I really enjoyed it. The developers put a lot of work into this game to ensure an awesome experience and they did a wonderful job.     Graphics - The graphics are amazing, hand-drawn and well-animated. There aren't too many spots in this action RPG where you can stop and enjoy the scenery but you have to stop occasionally and admire the gorgeous hand drawn graphics, and slick animations. You will also find that many portions of the environment are destructible, meaning you can attack walls and eventually fall off the level, or hide behind hedges which enemies will have to destroy to get to you. You are also occasionally treated with gorgeous still shots or character portraits.     Battle System - The battle system in Bastion is very unique. This is an Action RPG with a unique variety of weapons that let you choose how you want to play. You can choose ranged weapons or melee weapons or many of the hybrid weapons in between. Some battles require strategy and some just ask you to destroy everything that moves.     Additional Systems - There are also many additional systems in this game, you can craft upgrades for your weapons which add various bonuses or change the way the weapon works altogether. If you find the game to easy, you can also craft items that will make the enemies more powerful or handicap your character. Similarly, if you find the game too difficult, you can craft items that will provide passive bonuses to your character. You can also craft quest items that you can provide to the NPCs to hear tiny snippets that provide insight into the characters' past, or to flesh out parts of the overarching narrative.     Audio - The music in this game is excellent, and some of the most memorable 'tunes' I've heard in a game in a long time. Shortly through the game you will unlock a jukebox of sorts that lets you replay various music which is the point when you realize how good the music really is.     Replayability - The game is pretty linear throughout, but in the end, you are faced with two great choices which affect your final ending. I wouldn't say there is a lot of replayability once the story is over, unless you are a collectionist who wants every item, every upgrade, every skill, complete every level, etc. However, if you enjoyed the gameplay like me, that's your main attraction, and you don't care if you are trudging through the same story again. There is a New Game + function that lets you retain various perks and start a new game.     Value - I definitely got my money's worth with this game. Although the story was pretty short, I had a lot of fun and I passed by a few collectables that would have stretched out the story a bit more. I also go Bastion on sale from the Steam Summer Sale which was nice, but after having played it I would have paid full price for this game, it is definitely worth it.   Overall, I give Bastion a 9/10. It's an action packed adventure through a mysterious fantasy world that keeps you begging for more. Telling the story through the perspective of the narrator is a unique spin on the traditional outspoken action hero that makes the game feel fresh and different. The gorgeous artwork will leave you drooling and collectionists will enjoy the many extras this game has to offer. Get this one, you won't regret it. And let's all hope for a Bastion 2.

There's a lot of replayability here, as well, and this is coming from someone who practically never plays a completed game a second time. If you see this on sale, grab it quick.

This was one of those games I had heard about here and there, and when I saw it for sale, I thought, 'Hey. Why not.'  And then proceeded to ignore it for half a year.  Never have I regretted that choice more. Here's the breakdown:  Graphics: Everything looks to be meticulously detailed and painted with loving care. The colors are appropriately bright in some areas, whereas others induce feelings of despair and melancholy. The characters', when viewed from the general view, aren't extremely detailed (being rather small), but do get various painted panels, which are really nice to see, Overall, the medium used to present this game is wonderfully atmospheric, and makes Bastion one of the prettiest games I've seen in a while.  Soundtrack: It's fantastic. I really, really recommend buying the game with he soundtrack. Lots of emotional tracks, all of which seem to fit the game very nicely. I have no problem having these stuck in my head for the rest of the night.  Gameplay: It's fairly straightforward, though I would highly recommend playing with an xbox controller if at possible. Lots of the timed challenges will be much easier with those controls. I enjoyed how you could select any weapon combination you wanted, as well as how many ways you could customize each. A fun touch was the narrator commenting on whatever combination you selected. That's actually a really nice tough overall, how involved the narrator seems to be with your decisions. Another aspect of combat that was interesting was how most of the fights were very fast and exciting. I say most, because there were a few where you could win simply by shielding and lettings the enemy ricochet off you until it died. But for the most part, fast-paced and fun.   Story: This is what makes you marathon this game. Everything above complements the story and the way it's presented. The characters are sympathetic, though mysterious, and the story of the Calamity even more so. I very much felt like I had personal stakes in the outcome.   If the above is too much to read, just know it's worth buying and playing right away.

Kid thinks about what to write. Narrating ain't so easy, after all. But Bastion does it best - the way it should be.  Rucks is the best, as far as narrators go. When he starts talking, you're compelled to hang on to every word he says. His voice breathes life into the journey, puts the 'story' into history. He tells tales the way tales were meant to be told - the way that keeps you coming back for more.  Bastion is a piece of art. The character / stage / enemy design, battle animations, the voiceacting, and the music. Oh my god the music. Easily the most captivating part of the game. Zia's theme, Zulf's theme, and their subsequent mash up Setting Sail, Coming Home are influential musical landmarks for me.   There are a variety of weapons in Bastion, each requiring their own distinct style of play. You get to pick two weapons at a time to run through the game with, and I believe the many combinations that exist are all potential game-winning ones. Playing with the increased difficulty NG+ and beyond (activating all Pantheon Gods for example) ramps up the challenge level significantly - that's when certain weapons begin to shine more than others.  A very solidly grounded hack-and-slash-esque indie title which expands the traditional definition of the concept of a game. Enjoyed every minute of it.   Besides, very few things have since surpassed the shocked elation I experienced when I heard Zia speak for the first time.

Bastion - A game that was highly recommended by most of my friends immediately popped on my radar and was tagged to be played. Under the right circumstances and by that I mean the it was heavily discounted during one of the steam sales and I managed to acquire it. I had checked some of the reviews before hand and deemed it 'check-it-out worthy'. Having recently finished it I must admit that I have mixed feelings.  In summary, when I first launched the game I admired the visual style of the game. The audio was excellent to and by that I mean the soundtrack explicitly. The sound effects are fairly average. During my playthrough; mostly between start and finish, the game is pretty repetitive. The story does progress but in terms of gameplay you are not expected to do cartwheels and summersaults while juggling swords on fire. Mostly I found it really boring and couldn't wait to get to the end of the game. The end of the game was nothing fancy either. I mean a fairly expected conclusion to a decent story. The directors of the game let you play while there is a narrator with an odd wild west accent usually saying out loud what you have already done or are probably about to do.  The story itself is ok at best. Apart from the unusual setting there is nothing else note worthy about it. You have to do <insert> to restore some <insert> to achieve <insert>.  The visual style is amazing and I must say that is one of the 2 things about the game that is worth looking at. Although, having said that, It can sometimes be confusing how the map is laid out. In some cases you'd walk on air where wou'd expect to fall and in other cases you'll slip an edge where you expected to be able to walk just fine.  The audio is probably the best feature of the game and the soundtrack is amazing. I loved the songs in the game and more precisely the timing of those songs and their cue in the story.  In conclusion, I would say that this game is worth a shot but only if you can get it for really cheap. Let me start off by saying that Bastion won Best Downloadable Game at the 2011 VGX Awards as well as Best Song and Best Original Score and it shows! From the get-go you are introduced to the most compelling aspect of the game imho: its near-constant narration that's delivered with gravitas and is the primary method through which the story is told. I found myself completely drawn in and absorbed by the excellent voice acting and was made to feel like I was being read a story by a gifted grandfatherly figure. Speaking of the story, while many have criticized it for its lack of originality I loved it as you gradually learn of the shocking cause of the calamity that has befallen the world and how that knowledge affects its few remaining survivors. Not every game story has to have multiple twists and turns, it's totally fine for them to be simple but well-crafted. Further enhancing the story-book feel of the game are its lush and beautifully-drawn stages that are stunning to behold despite the fact that this is a 2D game. Next, the combat: another point of contention among some, it's been criticized as being too simple and lauded as having a deceptive depth to it. I myself am of a mind with the latter camp as I found the many combat options to be quite diverse and open to experimentation that allow you to customize your combat according to your playstyle. Finally, I'd be remiss if I didn't mention its fantastic musical score and song, 'Build That Wall' (written and composed by Darren Korb): my head kept bobbing to the excellent tunes and it's so good that I've since added the entire soundtrack (minus a song or 2) to my Spotify playlist and you very likely will to once you play this great game :)  9.5/10

(super-long and spoiler-free review as far as I can) Decided to play it to the end on easy mode before writting a review. Please forgive any writting mess as I'm not English-speaking/writting native.  Usually I'm not a plataformer game player (I usually mess when jumping and end dying a lot - and sure thing, I died a lot here)  Bastion is an interesting game where all the game talking is done by Rucks, an old man (who acts as the game narrative, he also makes some funny remarks) you (as the Kid, a silent protagonist) find in the Bastion, a place somehow safe from the Cataclysm, an event that broke (most of) the world. Said Bastion is the central base for Kid and need the Cores to be useful (they open shops and other useful structures), and after it is heavily damaged after an event, you need Shards to repair it. Some items also add interesting features, and open maps you can redo - these give some indeep info about Zulf and Zia, the two other characters you will find: Zulf and Zia. Zulf was an ambassador from Ura (a neighbour subterranean country which was in war with Kid's Caelondia years ago), Zia is a girl of Ura origin but born in Caelondia.  Equippables: You can use two weapons and a skill (linked with a wepon or having another useful feature). For weapons I chose to use both melee and ranged weapons (some mobs can and will munch you from distance). The weapons can be upgraded or switched in Bastion (you also find some Arsenals to change weapons on the maps, but thet are rare).  Two interesting features is the Spirits, drinks you can equip on slots you get one per level - they give some good bonuses (some also give disadvantages too); the other are the Gods; those give bonuses on XP and Scraps, but they also cam make the game much harder if you select more than one.  The game is quite linear, except for two situations near the game end where you decide what to do (I chose both right-side choices, won't spoil it here). Ending the game open the NewGame+ mode, where you start with all levels, gear, items and scraps (the $ here) from the 1st play, and you get new features on the new gameplay.  The music is incredible, when I heard Zia's song I was delighted to see that the singer on Transistor game is also here - I don't have Bastion soundtrack yet, will get it on a future sales.  Bastion is not a new game, and have a TON of positive reviews - if you never played it, get the demo (it's free) and try a bit - you won't be disappointed.

Oh wow.. Where to begin with the review for Bastion. There's much I would like to touch on, however the list would continually sprawl onwards for eternity, or at least until you lose interest, so, I'll keep it short. Bastion is a narrative-driven game narrated by an old man by the name of 'Rucks'. You traverse through the world with the narration of Rucks as you explore the areas known as The Wilds, on a quest to find a way to repair the safehaven for all known as 'The Bastion'.   I can honestly recommend this game to everyone, especially those with a hunger for an Action-RPG.  Pros: - The soundtrack is immaculate. There are moments where I'm sitting home playing other games and I will listen to it over the games native soundtrack.  - Combat is fluid and fair, never making it so you feel as though you are overpowered.   - A weapon upgrade system that is just the right amount of frustrating in terms of finding required materials, and the perfect amount of rewarding when your weapon is entirely upgraded.  - Ease of changing equipment within the hub world of 'The Bastion'. Allowing for multiple combinations of weaponry and skills.  - Unique Landscape Design, which may sound.. Odd to list here, however the ground beneath you forms as you traverse it, keeping you on edge as you explore for the next enemy which may be just around the corner.  - New Game+ Has ridiculous attention to detail, going so far as to have the narrator add audio cues which were not within the original runthrough of the game, as well as a new challenge mode.  - Extremely rewarding story and gameplay length. It took me a tad over 10 hours to complete my first playthrough of the game. The stories ending is extremely satisfying, with both choices having their own narrative and consequences.    Cons: - Skills became useless about a fourth of the way through the game. Whilst they may be interesting, there is no necessity or need for them within the game after you've learned how to clear a swath through your enemies with your main weaponry.  - Not having the ability to traverse back to lands which you have previously explored. Whilst this may fit within the storyline as an explanation, it is a tad weird for such an exploration emphasized game to falsely limit such.  - Spirits, while useful, not being required in any way, shape, or form. Spirits are upgrades you can apply onto your character for specific bonuses, however there are only about a handful of them worth using in any capacity past artifically imposing difficulty upon yourself, as some of their detirments outweigh their bonuses.  - Artificially imposed continuation of the game. Essentially in the form of leveling up. If you're someone who wants to do absolutely everything, you're looking at a game timespan of an upwards of at least 30 hours or more to achieve the highest level possible for the Spirits.  Overall, I absolutely adore this game, even with the few quirks I've mentioned above. I recommend it to anyone. If you're looking for a game which is cheap but don't want to purchase the game at its overall price of $15, wait until one of the sales periods and pick it up for $2 to $5. It is entirely worthwhile at that price point.

Bastion is an isometric action game with a fantasy, steampunk setting developed by Supergiant Games and published by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment.  Narrative:  The Good - Bastion has an interesting start of beginning during the immediate moments following a global cataclysm known as the Calamity, wiping out most of civilization. You take on the persona of 'The Kid', a teen who is on a mission to restore the world. The game opens itself up in an incredibly abrupt manner, but I feel like that's fitting. The story is focused and doesn't become sidetracked by unnecessary subplots. It's not the weirdest or the most unique story of all time, but it's well paced, for the most part, and seems perfect for the game. The game also, early on, introduces the narrator to the story, an old man with a mysterious past. The writing is cheesy enough to keep the game from becoming gloomy, however serious enough to not make me start laughing. There is also a ton of lore that is explained as the player progresses through levels and it seems really natural. The whole game feels extremely surreal and weird and the endings have an odd mixture of happy ending combined with a depressing aspect.  The Bad - This game's flaw is the characters. The game does a horrible job of making me sympathize with the characters. There are three levels where the narrator attempts to quickly make the characters relatable and people you should care for. Needless to say, it doesn't succeed. The narrator, on the other hand, has a lot of potential to be fleshed out and very interesting and he ends up getting shafted. So when I came to the decision of which ending should be chosen, the game thought I would feel bad for one of the other characters and reconsider saving civilization. That didn't work.   Score - 7.5/10  Graphics:  The Good - Bastion is beautiful. It runs at a smooth framerate, has some well flowing animations, and has not only one of the most well designed and detailed worlds out there, but one of the most vibrant color palettes that manages to be eye-catching, not eye-♥♥♥♥♥♥.  The Bad - The Kid's animation is stiff. Really stiff.  Score - 9/10  Sound:  The Good - There is a wide array of different musical types from calm serene flute music, to incredibly suiting action, western music, to southern, banjo music for swamps. It's fantastic. There are some incredibly catchy tracks in this one. the narrator is also awesome. At first, I was unsure about him but I ended up really enjoying his voice on my journey. The sound effects are also done very well and sound crisp, clear, and perfect.  The Bad - No problems.  Score - 10/10

Bastion is a game whose story is delivered by a third person omniscient narrator. The game starts in a broken world suspended in the sky. A catastrophe or calamity, how it is referred as in the game, just occurred but you have no recollections of any of the events. The narrator doesn’t speak about the characters emotional or psychological state, he simply narrates the actions being portrayed. He is also the one who tells the player the story of the world that it once was and what it is now. The entire context around the environment and the characters is being narrated whilst the player is experiencing them at first hand. Gameplay is fun and soundtrack fenomenal.

Quite frankly, this is among the best games I have ever played in my life, period. Bar none. Honestly, I would say the weakest part of the game is the game itself, and I find the gameplay to be amazing and intuitive. The weapons are complex and lead to interesting combinations when equipped together, and the combat is fluid and intuitive yet challenging.    However, this all pales in comparison to the rest of the game. The atmosphere is beautiful, the artstyle breathtaking, and the music... God, the music is probably my favorite soundtrack of all time. Darren Korb and Ashley Barret created something absolutely amazing.   The narration is spot on, the story is great, and though you get little agency along the way, the choices you do get are deep. Plot and backstory is told through dream scenes and snippets of memory, and is woven seamlessly into the narrative without taking away from forward plot progression.   Now I'm just rambling, because honestly there's just so much good to talk about. Buy this game. You will not regret it.
